trustfund:
TF020207-MAINSTREAMING GENDER ISSUES IN
            WB OPER.,TF034441-VENEZUELA - AGRICULTURE
            EXTENSION PROJECT,TF037137-VENEZUELA - AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION,TF037302-VENEZUELA - AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION,TF050624-PHRD-VENEZUELA: IMPLEMENTATION
            OF THE AGRICULTURAL EXTENSION

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Agricultural
            Extension Project for Venezuela were as follows: the outcome
            was satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory,. The
            lessons learned indicate that proposal of a co-financing
            matrix and specification of the flow of funds is not
            sufficient to guarantee co-financing from local governments,
            instead specific provisions need to be made. The issue of
            beneficiary contributions for agricultural services is more
            difficult. In the Venezuela case, there was an attitude on
            the part of project management that beneficiaries (poor
            farmers) should not pay. The type of extension services most
            requested by beneficiaries might not be what project
            designers envisaged. Specific provision was made in the
            Staff Appraisal Report (SAR) for Subject Matter Specialists
            (SMS) from research institutes to respond to requests from
            extensionists in the field. Initially this project
            didn't focus on Gender issues. However, once the
            extensionists started working in the communities it was
            obvious that women could play an important part in the
            project. The project specifically stated that the
            municipalities and the Producer Associations (ACEs) would
            supervise all extension contracts. Project preparation
            overestimated the local capacity to contract, supervise and
            evaluate the extension program. The establishment of a
            decentralized extension program needs to be accompanied by a
            strong training program of local organizations such as the
            municipalities and ACEs and should be planned accordingly
            with adequate resources.
